title: AI, networks and Mechanical Turks
snippet:
How far do LLMs give us a step change in how good a search and 
recommendation system can be? Do they let you build one without needing a 
vast user base of your own?

title: AI metrics
snippet:
With every platform shift, we want to measure the growth but we’re confused 
about what to measure. That’s partly a problem of data and definitions, but 
it’s really a question about what this is going to be.

title: GenAI’s adoption puzzle
snippet:
Generative AI chatbots might be a life-changing transformation in the 
nature of computing, that can replace all software, but so far, most of its 
users only pick it up every week or two, and far fewer have made it part of 
their lives. Is that a time problem or a product problem?

title: What kind of disruption?
snippet:
Software ate the world. Uber and Airbnb didn’t sell software - they 
disrupted and redefined markets. But what kind of disruption are we talking 
about ?

title: Apple innovation and execution
snippet:
It matters that Apple’s new Siri will be late, and it matters more that 
Apple didn’t realise. Is it more than that?

title: The Deep Research problem
snippet:
OpenAI’s Deep Research is built for me, and I can’t use it. It’s another 
amazing demo, until it breaks. But it breaks in really interesting ways.

title: Are better models better?
snippet:
Every week there’s a better AI model that gives better answers. But a lot 
of questions don’t have better answers, only ‘right’ answers, and these 
models can’t do that. So what does ‘better’ mean, how do we manage these 
things, and should we change what we expect from computers?

title: Competing in search
snippet:
A quarter century after ‘don't be evil’ a judge has found that Google is 
abusing its monopoly in search. But no-one knows what happens next, and 
whether this ruling will change anything. Will Apple build a search engine? 
Will ChatGPT change search? Does it matter?

title: The AI summer
snippet:
Hundreds of millions of people have tried ChatGPT, but most of them haven’t 
been back. Every big company has done a pilot, but far fewer are in 
deployment. Some of this is just a matter of time. But LLMs might also be a 
trap: they look like products and they look magic, but they aren’t. Maybe 
we have to go through the slow, boring hunt for product-market fit after 
all.

title: The VR winter continues
snippet:
Meta has spent at least $50bn on VR and AR so far, but we’re still in the 
VR winter: the devices aren’t good enough or cheap enough and the user base 
is flat. But no matter how good the devices get, how many people will care?

title: Apple intelligence and AI maximalism
snippet:
Apple has showed a bunch of cool ideas for generative AI, but much more, it 
is pointing to most of the big questions and proposing a different answer - 
that LLMs are commodity infrastructure, not platforms or products.

title: Building AI products
snippet:
How do we build mass-market products that change the world around a 
technology that gets things ‘wrong’? What does wrong mean, and how is that 
useful?

title: Ways to think about AGI
snippet:
How do we think about a fundamentally unknown and unknowable risk, when the 
experts agree only that they have no idea?

title: AI and problems of scale
snippet:
Generative AI means things that were always possible at a small scale now 
become practical to automate at a massive scale. Sometimes a change in 
scale is a change in principle.

title: Looking for AI use-cases
snippet:
We’ve had ChatGPT for 18 months, but what’s it for? What are the use-cases? 
Why isn’t it useful for everyone, right now? Do Large Language Models 
become universal tools that can do ‘any’ task, or do we wrap them in 
single-purpose apps, and build thousands of new companies around that?

title: The problem of AI ethics
snippet:
Can you write laws, or lay down ethical principles, for a technology that 
will be used in entirely different ways, for different purposes, in 
different industries? What does that mean if it’s changing entirely every 
18 months?

title: Who cares about tech regulation?
snippet:
Tech regulation gets a lot of headlines, and seems like a big deal, but 
most people in tech don’t seem to care much. It’s boring, and years away, 
but more fundamentally, it really doesn’t affect what people are working 
on.

title: A month of the Vision Pro
snippet:
The Vision Pro is amazing, but like the rest of VR and AR, Apple seems 
years away from the mass market. And if it gets there, how much will it 
matter?

title: Remaking the app store
snippet:
The EU has finally made Apple redesign the App Store, 15 years after we 
started arguing about it, and no-one is happy with the result. In the next 
few years there’ll be a lot of shouting and some giant fines, but in the 
end, nothing much will change.

title: Leaving Twitter
snippet:
I was on Twitter since 2007, and built a meaningful part of my career on 
it, and I won’t be posting at all for the foreseeable future.
